Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI: The Effects of Biochar Addition on Denitrification and Carbon Sequestration within a Restored Wetland
Award.AbstractNarration:
Salt marshes are important wetlands that perform essential ecosystem functions. They limit coastal erosion, mitigate storm effects, and are important buffer system between coastal and terrestrial ecosystems. These environments are also responsible for removing harmful greenhouse gases from the atmosphere including nitrous oxide and carbon dioxide. This project will aid in the restoration of a salt marsh environment located in Shanghai, China. The study will be conducted under the guidance of Dr. Xuechu Chen, an expert in ecological engineering. Dr. Chen has advanced the field in wetland restoration through his publication contributions and commitment to international communications and collaborations. The goal of the study is to enhance the natural chemical processes of salt marsh environments in an effort to remove harmful greenhouse gases from the atmosphere.

The proposed study seeks to investigate the effects of biochar addition on salt marsh restoration. Biochar is a soil enhancer that is often used to improve soil quality and can be a mechanism to mitigate greenhouse gas emissions. Biochar is expected to aid in nitrous oxide removal by enhancing the denitrification process through organic carbon additions. It has the potential to enhance plant growth and slows the return of carbon dioxide into the atmosphere, facilitating carbon sequestration. The study site, Bihaijinsha, is located within northern Hangzhou Wan Bay, Fengxian District, Shanghai. It is a restored salt marsh about 6000m2 that underwent sediment addition as part of the restoration process. Biochar will be added to designated plots within the study area. Through the use of a gas analyzer, the greenhouse gases fluxes of carbon dioxide and nitrous oxide will be monitored from these plots. It is expected that gas fluxes will decrease over time and plant growth will increase. The restoration technique proposed in this project will help restore the biogeochemical processes within a salt marsh environment, promoting essential ecosystem services.

This award under the East Asia and Pacific Summer Institutes program supports summer research by a U.S. graduate student and is jointly funded by NSF and the Chinese Ministry of Science and Technology.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Under the guidance of my EAPSI host, Dr. Xuechu Chen, of East China Normal University (ECNU) in Shanghai, China, I investigated the effects of biochar addition on salt marsh restoration and greenhouse gas emissions. Biochar is a soil enhancer that is often used to improve soil quality and can be a mechanism to mitigate greenhouse gas emissions. It has the potential to enhance plant growth and slows the return of carbon dioxide into the atmosphere, facilitating carbon sequestration. The majority of the research project consisted of a field experiment within Yingwuzhou Wetland Park, northern Hangzhou Wan bay, Jinshan District, Shanghai, China. The EAPSI program provided a unique opportunity to investigate a novel restoration technique that has the potential to impact future salt marsh restoration projects.  

The broader purpose of this experiment was to enhance the natural chemical processes of salt marsh environments in an effort to remove harmful greenhouse gases from the atmosphere and enhance carbon sequestration. Greenhouse gas emissions are connected to climate change progression, which makes research on techniques to mitigate emissions imperative. This project tested the hypothesis that biochar will enhance carbon dioxide removal from the atmosphere as well as mitigate methane emissions. Our field experiment took place within the constructed wetland, Yingwuzhou Wetland Park. We tested the impacts of biochar on the carbon dioxide (CO2) and methane (CH4) emissions of a Phragmites australis dominated salt marsh. Phragmites australis is a dominant salt marsh plant within China. The experiment showed that biochar addition lead to significantly more carbon dioxide uptake from the Phragmites australis plots. This result suggests that biochar can enhance carbon sequestration in salt marsh environments. However, biochar did not have a significant impact on methane emissions within this field experiment. We also conducted a lab experiment that suggested that biochar may be able to mitigate methane emissions in low salinity environments, but this theory needs further investigation.

Through the EAPSI program, I learned the value of international research and cultural enrichment, and gained a new collaboration with Dr. Xuechu Chen and his laboratory. Post-EAPSI, I am became a co-author for a manuscript that I helped edit with Dr. Chen’s post-doctoral student, which is currently in review for the journal, Water Research. We are also currently writing a manuscript for the research conducted during the EAPSI program to submit for publication. I will also be returning to China in the spring of 2019 to continue research with the Chen Laboratory.

The EAPSI program created a unique research opportunity that lead to an ongoing collaboration with the Chen Laboratory at ECNU. The EAPSI experience has encouraged further collaborations that will allow us to investigate how geographically and ecologically different salt marshes respond to similar environmental changes and stressors. Thus leading to published research that will benefit climate change scientists and society as we develop ways to mitigate climate change effects.
